g.title: leaf_11
g.text: The grimoire tools work with a structured text format which we call Orb.
This is an introduction to that format.

g.title: leaf_17
g.text: I call Orb a metalanguage, because it can by design include any other
structured text format within it. Provided it may be represented in utf-8!
This is no stricture in practice.

g.title: leaf_18
g.text: The Orb format aims to be equally useful for markup, literate programming,
configuration, data exchange, and the sort of interactive notebook which

g.title: leaf_19
g.text: The first parser and tool is Grimoire, which, as a bootstrap, is focused on
literate programming. This will in turn be the format for the tools in the

g.title: leaf_26
g.text: - Error free: An Orb document is never in a state of error. Any valid
utf-8 string is an Orb document.
- Line based: Orb files may be rapidly separated into their elements
by splitting into lines and examining the first few
- Humane: Orb is carefully designed to be readable, as is, by
- General: There are no characters such as <>& in HTML which must be
escaped. Orb codeblocks can enclose any other format,
including Orb format. Orb strings are «brace balanced»
and can enclose any utf-8 string as a consequence.

g.title: leaf_27
g.text: While it is possible to do some fancy things with Orb, it is also a
comfortable format to write a blog post, or put a few key-value pairs into
a config file. If you were to send an email in Orb format, the recipient

g.title: leaf_42
g.text: Orb documents are encoded in utf-8.

g.title: leaf_43
g.text: The core syntax is defined in terms of the reachable keys on a US keyboard.
This tradition is firmly entrenched in the mid teens, and I have no
designs on budging that at present. The miser in me likes that they're
a byte each. The lawyer in me insists that this isn't ASCII, which is a

g.title: leaf_44
g.text: We aren't at all reluctant to use Unicode characters as part of the format.
Grimoire «strings» are the most visible example of this, along with drawer
and fold icons, which are actual parts of an Orb document.

g.title: leaf_45
g.text: Grimoire is case sensitive and uses lower-snake-case for built-in English
phrases. There is a convention (see classes) that uses capitalization of

g.title: leaf_47
g.text: Orb is a format for text. There are many ways of writing text, but only one
way of encoding it that matters. There is a long tail of Unicode complexity,
and there are traces of Committee spattered all over it; nonetheless we
should be grateful that utf-8 won, in a world in which we still drive cars on
both possible sides of the road.

g.title: leaf_48
g.text: Note that while we have our [[own opinions about utf-8][httk://]] our vision of
heaven is backward-compatible with the inferior version foisted upon us by a

g.title: leaf_49
g.text: Bidirectional handling in a context that's indentation sensitive is an
example of something subtle. Orb format uses indentation in a few key places,
and a compliant parser will need to detect and respect RTL [tk?] markers.
Exactly how is spelled out under [[indentation][httk://]]

g.title: leaf_50
g.text: I'd love to get a Hebrew and/or Arabic fluent hacker on the project
early, to make sure this works correctly. I'll settle for Aramaic.

g.title: leaf_51
g.text: Another thing I want to get right is equivalence. If you have a
variable called "Glück" the compiler shouldn't complain if it's
rendered in either of the valid ways. For some sequences that's
"any of the valid ways". If we normalized your prose, you might
have problems later, so we don't want to solve it that way.

g.title: leaf_52
g.text: This consideration mostly applys to [[hashtags][httk://]] and
[[handles][httk://]]. The idea is that Orb files will respect all the
wacky typographic equivalences that Unicode has gifted us with.

g.title: leaf_58
g.text: The vexacious ASCII character 8 will never be found in an Orb document. If
encountered, it will be reduced to two spaces. Grimoire will complain.

g.title: leaf_59
g.text: It's not an /error/ mind you, it's a well-defined input that will become
two spaces. If encountered by one of my tools, the tabs will be permanently

g.title: leaf_60
g.text: Yes. This applies to your source code blocks as well. It is time we put

g.title: leaf_71
g.text: The major distinction in Orb is between prose and structure.

g.title: leaf_72
g.text: Prose is the default parsing state. It is far from unstructured from the
runtime perspective. Although this needn't be embedded in the parse
tree, Grimoire understands concepts such as paragraphs, words, punctuation,
capital letters, languages, and anything else proper to prose.

g.title: leaf_73
g.text: I refer to human languages, but Grimoire understands programming languages
also. In principle, all of them, it shouldn't be harder to add them than
it is to call them from shell, though getting a runtime rigged up to
another runtime always calls for some finesse to derive a good experience.

g.title: leaf_74
g.text: "Programming languages" is overly specific. Grimoire draws a distinction
between prose and structure. Blocks may contain either, or both.

g.title: leaf_75
g.text: Something that's nice about a language build on a prose/structure
relationship is that it can be error free. Anything *grym* can't build into

g.title: leaf_76
g.text: Markdown has this property. Sometimes you run into parsers which
build errors into Markdown, which is itself erroneous. If you [[RTFM]
you'll find the word "error" once. Helpfully explaining how Markdown

g.title: leaf_77
g.text: We do what we can to make the document look the same as it is
in fact structured. The intention with Orb files is that we work with them
aided by a linter, which lets us be lazy and still get consistent results.

g.title: leaf_78
g.text: The most important point in this section is that Orb documents do not have
errors and never fail to parse. You should be able to literally plug any
Orb parser into a source of entropy and end up with a document, since a
proper utf-8 decoder will drop any invalid bytes it sees.

g.title: leaf_83
g.text: The root concept of Orb is a document, which divides into one or more
sections. A section owns all structure or prose within it. This
paragraph is owned by «** Ownership» above, as are all the rest of the
blocks until the next section header.

g.title: leaf_90
g.text: Orb documents are chunked into sections entirely by their heading lines.
Within a section, prose and structure alike are organized into blocks.
The defining marker of blocks is blank lines.

g.title: leaf_91
g.text: This second paragraph is the second block of the «*** Blocking» section.
Taking a look at the source document, you'll see that I put (single)
newlines between lines, with an 78 column margin. That should be considered
good style. If you prefer to have each paragraph be its own line, have at.

g.title: leaf_92
g.text: A line is considered blank if it contains only Unicode spacemarks. Grimoire
will smoothly remove any such cruft and replace it with «\n\n». We also

g.title: leaf_107
g.text: [[Tags][httk://]] are used both to provide names to blocks in Orb format
and to specify various actions in knitting and weaving. They may be placed
above or below the block which they affect.

g.title: leaf_108
g.text: The cling rule specifies that a group 'clings' to another group when
it is closer to that group than the other group. Ties resolve down.

g.title: leaf_109
g.text: This should make it intuitive to group elements that aren't grouping the
way you expect: put in whitespace until the block is visually distinguished

g.title: leaf_110
g.text: Cling applies between blocks which are at the same level of ownership.
Ownership has precedence over cling: all blocks underneath e.g. a header
line are owned by that line, newlines notwithstanding.

g.title: leaf_111
g.text: Note that indentation of e.g. lists invokes the cling rule within the

g.title: leaf_130
g.text: Structure and prose are the figure and ground of Orb format. We speak of
structure and prose on a block-by-block basis, and within some structure
blocks there are regions of prose. Prose in turn routinely contains

g.title: leaf_131
g.text: This section will discuss under what circumstances an Orb parser will create
structure, with some discursions into the semantics these distinctions

g.title: leaf_138
g.text: Headlines divide a document into sections. The grammar for recognizing

g.title: leaf_140
g.text: The number of =*= determine the level of ownership. This is a declarative
relationship, though I lack a clean syntax to express it other than

g.title: leaf_141
g.text: The content within =prose= has the luxury of being context-sensitive. In
particular we treat tags on a headline as though they're on a tagline below

g.title: leaf_152
g.text: Tags are the control structures for Orb. There are =#hashtags= which
loosely correspond to functions or messages, and =@handles= which more

g.title: leaf_153
g.text: The semantics of tags belong in the [[runtime][httk://]]]] section.

g.title: leaf_154
g.text: For now let us note that the rule

g.title: leaf_156
g.text: *may* not appear in (all) prose contexts, this is still undecided. This is
true of handles as well given the state of =grym= at the present time,
but I am more firmly convinced of the value of @handle as a short in-place
expansion of a handleline. I don't think trying to parse a mid-block #export
as meaning something is as valuable.

g.title: leaf_157
g.text: These two rules are currently in use:

g.title: leaf_159
g.text: Structure is designed to work on a line-by-line basis,

g.title: leaf_174
g.text: Lists are both a markup format and a flexible data container. In the emacs
org-mode, headline-type structures do the heavy lifting for TODO lists and
the like. This was org's original purpose, with document markup coming later.

g.title: leaf_175
g.text: Orb lists come in unnumbered and numbered. Unnumbered lists follow this rule:

g.title: leaf_179
g.text: For lists, as with any structure group, the semantics of the prose section are
somewhat flexible. The cling rule for lists parses indentation so that

g.title: leaf_183
g.text: As in Markdown, the parser will accept any numbers as a numbered list without
checking their order. The linter will increment by one starting from the
number of the first index, so if you start with "1. " or "0. " or "10. " you
get the subsequent. This behavior can be suppressed with a hashtag directive

g.title: leaf_192
g.text: Lists can have, as a first element, a box, either a checkbox =[ ]= or a
radio box =( )=. These are either empty with whitespace or have contents
from a limited pallete of symbols. Their function is described in the

g.title: leaf_194
g.text: These two types can't meaningfully mix on the same level of a list. The one
the parser sees first will be applied.

g.title: leaf_195
g.text: The radio button is contagious, if the parser encounters one all lines on

g.title: leaf_196
g.text: The check box is not, it's ok to include it on some lines but not others. If
the parser sees a check box and then a radio button, it will turn the radio

g.title: leaf_197
g.text: The radio button can only have one =*=; the parser will ignore, and the

g.title: leaf_203
g.text: A list element can consist of key/value pairs, separated with a =:=.

g.title: leaf_205
g.text: From the runtime perspective the left and right sides are basically strings,
as we build out the Clu runtime we'll have better expectations for what
keys and values would look like as data.

g.title: leaf_217
g.text: The reason Orb exists is so that Grimoire can exist. We do codeblocks

g.title: leaf_220
g.text: Try that trick in Git-Flavored Markdown...

g.title: leaf_221
g.text: The number of initial =!!= needs to match the closing =//=, allowing any
utf-8 string at all to be enclosed with this method. We consider this an
important property to have in an enclosure encoding.

g.title: leaf_222
g.text: Code blocks must be opened, but needn't be closed, as a parser will recognize
EOF as a code block closure. This has a fortunate side effect, as this:

g.title: leaf_224
g.text: Is a valid Orb document containing a python script.

g.title: leaf_225
g.text: Codeblock headers and footers, unlike most structure lines, cannot begin

g.title: leaf_236
g.text: Tables are our matrix data structure. I have no immediate use for
spreadsheets that I can't meet with other software, but admire their
inclusion in Org and do use tables in markup from time to time.

g.title: leaf_237
g.text: I don't intend to do much more than recognize them in the near future,
but a glance at what Org offers with tables should give a sense of how
we want to use them within =bridge=.

g.title: leaf_239
g.text: With a couple small refinements, this one should render with a line

g.title: leaf_241
g.text: To extend a row virtually over two or more text lines

g.title: leaf_243
g.text: The only way to slip a =|= into a table cell is to put it inside a
«string». Other than that it's prose country.

g.title: leaf_249
g.text: The most [[basic link][httk://]] follows a simple «[[description]
[url]]» pattern. Markdown gets this right. In HTML you'll see the
href before the link text, but looking at HTML is a mistake.

g.title: leaf_250
g.text: Org-mode follows the opposite convention. This breaks the flow of text for
the reader and Orb format must be legible in raw form.

g.title: leaf_260
g.text: A drawer is a block that's hidden by default. The computer sees it,
the user sees ⦿, or a similar rune.

g.title: leaf_262
g.text: This closes to a single Unicode character, such as ⦿, which can't be deleted
without opening it. Deleting into an ordinary fold marker opens the fold,
deleting towards a drawer marker skips past it.

g.title: leaf_263
g.text: =a-drawer= is a handle, the @ isn't needed here but you could include it.
It's ok to just leave it blank: =:[ ]:=.

g.title: leaf_264
g.text: The only purpose of a drawer is to draw a folding layer around some text
that's normally kept closed. If you're doing something fancy you might
have a long header of imports and configs that you don't want to look at

g.title: leaf_265
g.text: Honestly not sure I'm going to bother implementing this part. Late in the
